edge: In this context, Aang is referred to as an 'Avatar'. Avatar is a specific term used in the world of Avatar: The Last Airbender to describe a powerful being who has mastery over all four elements (air, water, fire, and earth).
In this context, Aang is able to control the element of air. This ability allows him to fly, create gusts of wind, and manipulate air currents.
In this context, Aang is able to control the element of water. This ability allows him to create waves, manipulate bodies of water, and form ice sculptures.
In this context, Aang is able to control the element of fire. This ability allows him to create flames, manipulate temperatures, and generate explosive blasts.
In this context, Aang is able to control the element of earth. This ability allows him to move and manipulate large masses of earth, create tunnels and paths, and form solid constructs.

In this context, the Fire Nation is attempting to conquer other nations (specifically the Water Tribes and the Earth Kingdom). This act of conquest is a hostile and aggressive action taken by one nation against another.
In this context, the Fire Nation is attempting to conquer the Water Tribes. This act of conquest is a hostile and aggressive action taken by one nation against another.
In this context, the Fire Nation is attempting to conquer the Earth Kingdom. This act of conquest is a hostile and aggressive action taken by one nation against another.

In this context, 'The Last Airbender' refers to Aang, who is the last surviving airbender and the only one with the ability to control all four elements. This makes him a powerful and important figure in the world of Avatar: The Last Airbender.

Before Slumdog Millionaire was released, Patel auditioned for the role of Zuko by submitting a tape to the studio. Shyamalan called Patel personally to inform him that he got the part. While he was filming Slumdog in India, he would finish a take and turn one of the channels over to the animated series. Even though it is based on a cartoon, he wanted to bring as much of himself as possible to the character he was portraying.
Patel played the role of Zuko in the film. Training for the film was intense, as he had to learn Wushu and different martial arts.

Shaun Toub, who played Iroh in the animated series, describes Zuko in the first film as 'loose' and 'free'. He compares Zuko's 'obsession' to his childhood memories and how kids are always looking for their parents' approval, saying that Zuko just wants his father's.
Toub says Patel was able to influence him into appreciating the business of filmmaking more.

The fact that the casting seemed racially backward triggered negative reactions from fans as they accused it of going against the message of acceptance and cultural diversity advocated by the original series.
The casting of white actors in the East Asian and Inuit-influenced Avatar universe triggered negative reactions from fans marked by accusations of racism.
As a result of the casting, the Media Action Network for Asian-Americans also called for a boycott of the film.

Pre-production for the film began in late 2008.
Filming for the movie began on March 13, 2009 in Greenland.
In March 2009, filming for the movie took place in Greenland.
After two weeks of filming in Greenland, the cast and crew moved to Reading, Pennsylvania where production designers worked for several weeks preparing the location for the movie.
After two weeks of filming in Greenland, the cast and crew moved to Reading, Pennsylvania where special effects crews worked for several weeks preparing the location for the movie.
During production in Reading, Pennsylvania, a production team discovered the Pagoda on Mount Penn and used it as an ancient temple in the movie.
According to Reading mayor Tom McMahon, crews working on the movie made road improvements around the Pagoda on Mount Penn during production in Reading, Pennsylvania.
According to Reading mayor Tom McMahon, crews working on the movie buried electrical lines around the Pagoda on Mount Penn during production in Reading, Pennsylvania.

node_2: visual effects needed to tell the story
edge: Pablo Helman, the visual effects supervisor for the Industrial Light and Magic team on the film, worked with Shyamalan to review each scene and discuss the necessary visual effects. The Budd Company complex was fitted out as a studio to reflect the director's vision, and ultimately, Helman worked with about 300 people to bring it all to life.

The production crew filmed inside the abandoned Budd Company complex across the street from the production offices leased from Temple University Health System at its corporate offices located at 2450 West Hunting Park Avenue.
The production crew finished filming in the Pagoda and then continued shooting in Ontelaunee Township.
The production crew also filmed at the William Penn Memorial Fire Tower in Pennsylvania after finishing filming at the Pagoda.

node_2: visualizing elemental tribes of air, water, earth, and fire
edge: Tasked with visualizing the elemental tribes of Air, Water, Earth, and Fire; most importantly creating the 'bending' styles of these elements.
Required to animate creatures and enhance stunt work with digital doubles.
Helman shares that 'The work was challenging,' while figuring out what 'bending' is for fire
Fire and water were the hardest elements to effectively bend due to reality-based expectations.
Fire and water were the hardest elements to effectively bend due to reality-based expectations.

node_2: particle work which was unable to be rendered in hardware
edge: Earth bending also was difficult to create because of particle work which was unable to be rendered in hardware.
The concept for air was derived from the animation of the television series.
Seeing dust and snow particles, rather than seeing the air itself, helped shape the real-world effect of bending the element.
Before the bending effects could be applied, though, the actor's movements had to be matched; Shyamalan wanted each character's bending styles to be unique to fit with their unique personalities.
The challenge for fire did not come with making it look realistic, but rather making the fire behave in an unrealistic way that would be believable to the audience.

The team referenced images of flames being pushed through the air by giant fans for certain shots needed throughout the film, reflecting two-dimensional simulations that inspired The Last Airbender's fire style.
The team considered using a meshed image of real and digital fire for certain shots needed throughout the film, but in the end, went with the richer, deeper texture of computer-generated flame.
The team went with the richer, deeper texture of computer-generated flame for certain shots needed throughout the film.

In the climax of the film, the set measuring 200 by 200 feet had to be merged with stills of Greenland landscapes due to the long-duration shots in which the camera always moved. The low-angle lighting that was captured on location there also had to be incorporated.

In order to create a realistic merger between the set and stills in the climax, multiple cameras were utilized to achieve different wire-work and animation. The stills were then imported into the computer to animate the camera and get angles needed for different shots.
In creating Momo's flying mechanics, the team looked at various real-world creatures such as giant fruit bats to influence the look of the lemurs' wings.
To make each species distinct, hybrids from different animals were produced based on examples of the same size and weight as the animated character.
The team looked at various real-world creatures to get a take on how they would act in order for the animated characters to be believable.

Paramount Pictures announced in late April 2010 that The Last Airbender would be released in 3D due to an increasing number of films being made or converted to 3D, such as Avatar, Alice in Wonderland and Clash of the Titans, making a decent profit at the box office. While M. Night Shyamalan stated that The Last Airbender's way of shooting without fast edits and visuals could lend itself well to the 3D conversion process, James Cameron voiced his disapproval on any film being converted using this process, stating there was no possible way it could be done up to a standard considered high enough. Despite this, Shyamalan opted to work with Stereo D LLC, the company who worked on James Cameron's own Avatar, for the conversion process, which cost between $5 million and $10 million.
M. Night Shyamalan is the director of The Last Airbender.
James Cameron's Avatar was one of many films being made or converted to 3D, such as Alice in Wonderland and Clash of the Titans, that made a decent profit at the box office.

The Last Airbenger holds an approval rating of 5%, based on 192 reviews with an average rating of 3/10, making it the lowest-rated film produced by Nickelodeon Movies, as well as Shyamalan's worst-reviewed film to date.
This distinction is attributed to the film due to its unfavorable critical reception, with a weighted average score of 20 out of 100 on Metacritic based on 33 reviews.
The film is described as being produced by Nickelodeon Movies, which further contributes to its distinction as the lowest-rated production from that studio.
M. Night Shyamalan is credited with directing and producing this film, earning it the distinction of being his least favorably received work as of now.
This movie is listed on Rotten Tomatoes with a 5% approval rating, based on 192 reviews and an average score of 3/10.
The website's critical consensus statement reads, 'The Last Airbender squanders its popular source material with incomprehensible plotting, horrible acting, and detached joyless direction.'
When polled by CinemaScore, audiences gave this film an average rating of 'C' on the A+ to F scale.
Liam Lacey of The Globe and Mail stated that the film had little chance to develop its characters and therefore suffered, with the overall storyline of the film becoming a run-on narrative.
According to Owen Gleiberman from Entertainment Weekly, who gave the film a C, 'The Last Airbender keeps throwing things at you, but its final effect is, in every way, flat.'
Roger Ebert of the Chicago Sun-Times gave the film half a star in his review, stating that it 'bores and alienates its audiences.'

Keith Phipps of The A.V. Club gave the film an F, criticizing the performances of the child actors, overuse of exposition, and 'shoehorned 3D special effects,' calling it the worst summer blockbuster of 2010.

Peter Bradshaw of The Guardian noted an unfortunate linguistic problem that reduced British viewers to 'a state of nervous collapse' due to laughter.
